{{Infobox video game | image = God of War Ascension.jpg | developer = [[SCE Santa Monica Studio]] | publisher = [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] | series = ''[[God of War (franchise)|God of War]]'' | platforms = [[PlayStation 3]] | released = {{Collapsible list|titlestyle=font-weight:normal;background:transparent;text-align:left;|title=March 12, 2013|{{Video game release|NA|March 12, 2013|EU|March 13, 2013|AU|March 14, 2013|UK|March 15, 2013}}}} | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]], [[hack and slash]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | director = Todd Papy | producer = Whitney Wade | designer = Mark Simon | programmer = Vassily A. Filippov | artist = Christopher Sutton | writer = [[Marianne Krawczyk]] | composer = [[Tyler Bates]] | alt = Cover art featuring the protagonist Kratos }}
'''''God of War: Ascension''''' is a [[Third-person (video games)|third-person]] [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] video game developed by [[SCE Santa Monica Studio|Santa Monica Studio]] and published by [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] (SCE). The game was first released on March 12, 2013, for the [[PlayStation 3]] (PS3) console. It is the seventh installment in the [[God of War (franchise)|''God of War'' series]] and [[prequel]] to the entire series. Loosely based on [[Greek mythology]], the game is set in [[ancient Greece]] with vengeance as its central motif. The player controls the protagonist [[Kratos (God of War)|Kratos]], the former servant of the God of War [[Ares]], who tricked Kratos into killing his wife and daughter. In response to this tragedy, Kratos renounced Ares, breaking his blood oath to the god. Kratos was therefore imprisoned and tortured by the three [[Erinyes|Furies]], guardians of honor and enforcers of punishment. Helped by the oath keeper [[Horkos|Orkos]], Kratos escapes his imprisonment and confronts the Furies to be completely free of his bond to Ares.
The gameplay is similar to previous installments, focusing on [[Combo (video gaming)|combo-based]] combat with the player's main weapon—the Blades of Chaos—and other weapons acquired by the new World Weapons [[Game mechanics|mechanic]]. It continues the use of [[quick time event]]s and adds a new, promptless, free-form system. Four magical attacks and a power-enhancing ability can be used as alternative combat options, and the game features [[Puzzle video game|puzzles]] and [[platform game|platforming]] elements. ''Ascension'' is the only installment in the series to include [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]], which is [[Online game|online-only]] and features modes for both [[Player versus player|competitive]] and [[Cooperative gameplay|cooperative]] play. It also features a redesigned combat system, new gameplay mechanics, and [[downloadable content]]. From October 2012 to March 2013, a [[Social network game|social experience]] was available online in the form of a [[graphic novel]] titled ''[[#Rise of the Warrior|Rise of the Warrior]]'', a prequel story that tied into the game's single-player and multiplayer modes.
''God of War: Ascension'' received generally favorable reviews from critics, who praised its fundamental gameplay and spectacle as true to the series, although the story was generally deemed to be less compelling than previous installments. The game's multiplayer element received mixed responses: although reviewers found that the gameplay translated well into the multiplayer element, they criticized the balance and depth of combat. ''Ascension'' did not perform as well as its predecessors in terms of sales and awards, but it did receive several nominations, including the [[Writers Guild of America]] Videogame Awards's "Outstanding Achievement in Videogame Writing" and the [[Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences]] award for "Outstanding Achievement in Sound Design".
==Gameplay== {{further|Common gameplay elements in the God of War series}} In both of ''God of War: Ascension''{{'}}s [[single-player video game|single-player]] and [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] elements, it is primarily a [[Third-person (video games)|third-person]] video game viewed from a [[Virtual camera system#Fixed|fixed camera]] perspective. Some scenes in the single-player campaign feature a [[First-person (video games)|first-person]] camera view. In single-player mode, the player controls the character [[Kratos (God of War)|Kratos]] in [[Combo (video gaming)|combo-based combat]], [[Platform game|platforming]], and [[Puzzle video game|puzzle games]]. The enemies are an assortment of creatures, most of whom are drawn from [[Greek mythology]], including [[cyclops|cyclopes]], [[cerberus]]es, [[empusa]]s, [[Siren (mythology)|Siren]]s, [[Gorgons]], [[satyr]]s, [[harpies]], and [[centaurs]]. Other monsters were created specifically for the game, such as the juggernauts, wraiths, and [[manticore]]s. Many of the monsters also appear in the multiplayer mode. Platforming elements require the player to climb walls and ladders, jump across chasms, and slide down walls to proceed through sections of the game. The game features a variety of puzzles, ranging from simple to complex.<ref name="multicon">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2012-04-30-god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-confirmed |title=God of War: Ascension multiplayer confirmed |date=April 30, 2012 |last=Yin-Poole |first=Wesley |publisher=Eurogamer Network |work=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=April 30, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch5gtwbL?url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2012-04-30-god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-confirmed |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref name="manual">{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|p=5|ref=manual}}</ref>
===Combat=== Kratos' main weapon is the Blades of Chaos, a pair of blades attached to chains that are wrapped around his wrists and forearms. In gameplay, the blades can be swung offensively in various maneuvers. A new weapons [[Game mechanics|mechanic]] called the World Weapon system allows Kratos to pick up weapons scattered throughout game locations or to take them from defeated foes, and to use these for a limited time. There are five World Weapons (sword, club, javelin, sling, shield) that can be collected randomly, although Kratos may possess only one at any time.<ref name="manual"/><ref name="pg14">{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|p=14|ref=manual}}</ref> When a World Weapon is not equipped, Kratos may punch or kick foes as part of the new combat system.<ref name="Hands on"/> Another new mechanic is that Kratos can [[tether]] enemies, referred to as grappling; he can hold an enemy in place with one blade while he attacks other enemies with the other blade, and he can throw the tethered enemy.<ref name="pg14"/>
Four [[Magic (gaming)|magical]] disciplines are acquired, including the Fire of Ares, the Ice of Poseidon, the Lightning of Zeus, and the Soul of Hades, which, depending on the magic equipped, imbues the Blades of Chaos with that elemental property. For example, the Soul of Hades imbues the Blades with purple flames and can unleash souls of the Underworld to briefly attack enemies. The Ice of Poseidon also enables Kratos to breathe underwater, a necessary ability as substantial time is spent there.<ref name="Hands on">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/02/07/hands-on-with-god-of-war-ascension/ |title=Hands-On with God of War: Ascension |date=February 7, 2013 |last=Shuman |first=Sid |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=February 7, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EGpYdUoZ?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/02/07/hands-on-with-god-of-war-ascension/ |archivedate=February 8, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|p=15|ref=manual}}</ref> The Rage [[Superpower (ability)|ability]] called Rage of the Gods that was featured in previous games is included, but in this game, its meter is filled by landing attacks on enemies and the ability is automatically activated once the meter has reached maximum capacity. It remains activated until Kratos is attacked or stops attacking for an extended period of time, after which the meter must be refilled. The Rage ability is also affected by the magic equipped, allowing Kratos to use different Rage attacks, such as the lightning-based Rage of Zeus.<ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|p=6|ref=manual}}</ref>
Three relics, the Amulet of Uroborus (Life Cycle mechanic), the Oath Stone of Orkos, and the Eyes of Truth, are acquired and needed for game progression. The Amulet of Uroborus allows Kratos to manipulate time by decaying or healing an object; examples include reconstructing broken pathways and using it during puzzle-solving. Construction can be paused or reversed if needed. The amulet can also be used against enemies to briefly slow their movements. The Oath Stone of Orkos gives Kratos the ability to create a "shadow" duplicate of himself that can depress plates, hold levers, or attack enemies. The Eyes of Truth remove illusions created by the Furies and cast a blinding light on enemies.<ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|pp=16–17|ref=manual}}</ref> As well as the [[quick time event]] (QTE) mechanic featured in the previous games, a new, promptless, free-form system allows players to choose when to attack or dodge based on the enemy's actions. When certain foes, such as a cyclops or a juggernaut, have been sufficiently weakened, the player may jump on their back and briefly force them to attack other foes.<ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|pp=17–18|ref=manual}}</ref>
Other extra features include ten artifacts hidden in the game world that provide more abilities during [[New Game Plus]], such as unlimited magic. This mode also allows players to change Kratos' costume, but [[PlayStation Network#Trophies|trophies]] are disabled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2013/03/06/future-god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-map-packs-will-be-free-single-player-includes-a-new-game-plus-mode/ |title=Future God of War: Ascension Multiplayer Map Packs Will be Free, Single Player Includes a "New Game Plus Mode" |date=March 6, 2013 |last=Dunning |first=Jason |publisher=[[CraveOnline]] |work=[[PlayStation LifeStyle]] |accessdate=February 24, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X6BRfk8W?url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2013/03/06/future-god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-map-packs-will-be-free-single-player-includes-a-new-game-plus-mode/ |archivedate=March 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> A new feature absent from previous installments is "Chapter Select", which allows players to select and replay previously completed levels. Unlike previous installments, in which behind-the-scenes videos are unlocked after completing the game, these videos are already available from the main menu.<ref>{{cite video game|title=''God of War: Ascension''|developer=[[SCE Santa Monica Studio]]|publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment]]|year=2013|platform=[[PlayStation 3]]|scene=Main Menu Screen}}</ref>
===Multiplayer=== [[File:GOWAscension MP.jpg|thumb|left|300px|A portion of the Desert of Lost Souls multiplayer map: players (seen on right) battle each other with the [[Titan (mythology)|Titan]] [[cyclops]] [[Polyphemus]] in the background. If players get close to Polyphemus, he will attack them.<ref name="Kaufman">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/07/05/the-monsters-of-god-of-war-ascension-polyphemus/ |title=The Monsters of God of War: Ascension – Polyphemus |date=July 5, 2012 |last=Kaufman |first=Aaron |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=July 6, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch5jIeJJ?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/07/05/the-monsters-of-god-of-war-ascension-polyphemus/ |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>]]
''God of War: Ascension'' is the only installment in the series to offer a multiplayer feature, which is [[Online game|online-only]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ps3.ign.com/articles/122/1223989p1.html |title=The Multiplayer Madness of God of War: Ascension |date=April 30, 2012 |last=Moriarty |first=Colin |publisher=[[Ziff Davis Media]] |work=[[IGN]] |accessdate=April 30, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch5fl19s?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/04/30/the-multiplayer-madness-of-god-of-war-ascension |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> and up to eight players can take part. The main objective for players is to take control of a map to earn rewards from the gods. Before entering multiplayer battles, each player is introduced to a warrior, who, like Kratos, is an oath-breaker and is imprisoned in the Prison of the Damned—the warrior's backstory is explored in ''[[#Rise of the Warrior|Rise of the Warrior]]''. The player takes control of the warrior and aligns with one of the four deities: Ares,<ref name="Ares"/> Hades,<ref name="Hades"/> Zeus,<ref name="Rise"/> or Poseidon.<ref name="Poseidon"/><ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|p=19|ref=manual}}</ref> Each god offers a unique combat play-style and in-battle abilities. The attack style of the god with whom the player aligns is critical to their warrior's path.<ref name="beta"/> Players who ally with Ares are brute force experts with an up-close focus, although they are weak defensively, specifically to long range magical attacks. Players who ally with Zeus are magical experts with a focus on space control, although they are balanced by their lack of melee strength. Players who ally with Poseidon are supports with a focus on team synergy and self-sustenance; his synergistic powers can be replaced by more self-defense abilities if desired, although never as much as the other 3 gods. Players who ally with Hades are versatile, unlike the other 3, featuring other unique mechanics such as lifesteal, stealth and curses, making them excellent at controlling the flow of combat, although they can also choose to specialize in certain roles with certain armors or weaponry. Players can create up to three more warriors and have a champion representing each god.<ref name="mpw"/>
Players can unlock special magic abilities, new and upgraded armors, weapons, relics, and other treasures as they earn experience points (XP) to level-up their warrior.<ref name="mpw">{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|pp=20–22|ref=manual}}</ref> Players may also complete "Labors", which are challenges from the gods that rewards armor and weapons.<ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|p=9|ref=manual}}</ref> Throughout multiplayer matches, players receive [[Status effect#Buffs and debuffs|buffs and debuffs]],<ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|p=7|ref=manual}}</ref> and there is a color-coding system, called flashes, where a player's character will flash a certain color indicating a special property, such as vulnerability or invulnerability.<ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|p=25|ref=manual}}</ref> A prestige feature called "Ascension", added in the June 10, 2013 [[Patch (computing)#Video games|update]], allows players to reset their allegiance progression when they reach Level 40, and receive in-game currency for "Godly" armors and weapons—the "most valuable and powerful items in the game".<ref name="prestige"/> They are classified as a Hero the first time they ascend and then a Demigod the second time and keep that title from then on.<ref name="prestige">{{cite web|url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2013/06/10/god-of-war-ascension-patch-1-08-now-live-brings-along-the-ascension-feature/ |title=God of War: Ascension Patch 1.08 Now Live, Brings Along the Ascension Feature |date=June 10, 2013 |last=Dunning |first=Jason |publisher=[[CraveOnline]] |work=[[PlayStation LifeStyle]] |accessdate=February 9, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6fAl3hlHX?url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2013/06/10/god-of-war-ascension-patch-1-08-now-live-brings-along-the-ascension-feature/ |archivedate=February 9, 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
There are five multiplayer modes: Team Favor of the Gods, Match of Champions, Trial of the Gods, [[Capture the Flag]], and Bout of Honor. Team matches randomly assign players to compete on either the [[Sparta]]n or [[Troy|Trojan]] team. The "signature" multiplayer mode is Team Favor of the Gods, in which two teams of two-to-four players try to win by accumulating a target quantity of points. Points, known as Favor, are earned by killing and other methods. When players are not on the offensive, they may help their team earn points by capturing altars, collecting red orbs from chests, and setting traps for opposing players. The non-team version, Match of Champions, is a four-to-eight-player [[deathmatch]] with a similar goal to Team Favor of the Gods.<ref name="Jan8">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/12/12/god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-beta-available-to-ps-plus-members-january-8th/ |title=God of War: Ascension Multiplayer Beta Available to PS Plus Members January 8th |date=December 12, 2012 |last=Osgood |first=Derek |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=December 12, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CrYETJHQ?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/12/12/god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-beta-available-to-ps-plus-members-january-8th/ |archivedate=December 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Trial of the Gods is a two-player, cooperative (co-op), [[Time attack#Video games|time-trial]] mode in which the duo faces five waves of mythological monsters concluding with a boss fight. A single-player version is also available.<ref name="Poseidon">{{cite web|title=God of War: Ascension: Trial of the Gods Revealed |url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/03/06/god-of-war-ascension-trial-of-the-gods-revealed/ |date=March 6, 2013 |last=Chrysafidis |first=Andrew |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=March 6, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EvritWQn?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/03/06/god-of-war-ascension-trial-of-the-gods-revealed/ |archivedate=March 7, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> In Capture the Flag, two teams of four players battle to capture the opposing team's flag and return it to their base until a target number of flags have been obtained.<ref>{{Harvnb|SCE Santa Monica Studio, ed.|(2013)|pp=24–25|ref=manual}}</ref> In Bout of Honor, added in the July 11, 2013 update, players test their skills in a best-of-seven-rounds one-on-one fight.<ref name="1.09">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/07/11/god-of-war-ascension-1v1-multiplayer-mode-new-maps-out-now/ |title=God of War: Ascension: 1v1 Multiplayer Mode, New Maps Out Now |date=July 11, 2013 |first=Quentin |last=Ramsey |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=July 11, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X6BfXApw?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/07/11/god-of-war-ascension-1v1-multiplayer-mode-new-maps-out-now/ |archivedate=March 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
All but two of the fifteen multiplayer maps are based on locations explored throughout the ''God of War'' series, with eight of those based on locations explored in ''Ascension''; for example, Desert of Lost Souls is from the original ''[[God of War (2005 video game)|God of War]]'', Bog of the Forgotten is from ''[[God of War II]]'', and Labyrinth of Daedalus, Forum of Hercules, and Chamber of the Flame are from ''[[God of War III]]''.<ref name="Jan 8"/> The two original maps are the Coliseum of [[Persia]] and the Walls of [[Troy]] (which features the [[Trojan Horse]]). Every map features special power-ups awarded by the gods for earning points, such as the Boots of Hermes for acceleration and running attacks.<ref name="beta"/><ref name="mpw"/> Maps also have environmental obstacles or objectives to complete for more points. For example, on the Desert of Lost Souls map, the cyclops Polyphemus may attack nearby players and killing him with the Spear of [[Mount Olympus|Olympus]] will grant bonus points for that team.<ref name="Kaufman"/><ref name="Joystiq preview"/>
==Synopsis==
===Setting=== As with previous games, ''God of War: Ascension'' is set in an alternate version of [[ancient Greece]] populated by the [[Twelve Olympians|Olympian Gods]], [[Titan (mythology)|Titans]], and other beings from Greek mythology. Game events are set six months after Kratos killed his family, and ten years before the original ''God of War'' (2005). The next game chronologically would be ''Chains of Olympus'' (2008), which takes place some time between ''Ascension'' and ''God of War'' (2005). The game's narrative takes place over four weeks; it shifts between the present (the fourth week) and past (the preceding three weeks), while the player controls Kratos in both. Several locations, including the Prison of the Damned and some real-world locations—including the village [[Kirra, Phocis|Kirra]], the city [[Delphi]], and the island [[Delos]]—are explored in the game.
The Prison of the Damned is the Furies' massive prison to house all oath-breakers. Kirra is an abandoned village that lost its water supply after its [[water wheel]] and [[Aqueduct (bridge)|aqueduct]] were destroyed. Other than monsters, the only life is in its harbor, where the tamed [[Laestrygonian|Harbor Master]] guides vessels in and out of the port. Delphi is located in the snowy mountains north of Kirra and features the Tower of Delphi. After activating three massive, mechanical pythons, the Tower allows access to the Temple of Delphi, home of the Oracle. Delos features a Titan-sized statue of [[Apollo]], constructed by the inventor [[Archimedes]] to honor the god.
===Characters=== {{main|Characters of God of War}} The game's protagonist is Kratos (voiced by [[Terrence C. Carson]]), a Spartan warrior who broke his blood oath to the god [[Ares]] after being tricked into killing his family by his former master. The main antagonists are the three [[Erinyes|Furies]]: [[Megaera]] ([[Nika Futterman]]), [[Tisiphone]] ([[Debi Mae West]]), and the Fury Queen, [[Alecto]] ([[Jennifer Hale]]). The Furies are the guardians of honor and the bane of traitors, who punish those they deem guilty. They were spawned from the eons-long war between the [[Greek primordial deities|Primordials]], the beings who created the Earth. Other characters include the oath keeper [[Horkos|Orkos]] ([[Troy Baker]]), the son of Ares and Alecto, who was disowned by the god as he was not the perfect warrior that Ares sought; [[Pythia|Aletheia]] ([[Adrienne Barbeau]]), the Oracle of Delphi with prophetic sight; the corrupted Prophet [[Castor and Pollux|Castor]] (David W. Collins) and his conjoined twin [[Castor and Pollux|Pollux]] (Brad Grusnick), who usurped the oracle, deciding who can consult her; and the Scribe of Hecatonchires ([[Robin Atkin Downes]]), the first mortal imprisoned by the Furies who has been keeping records to maintain his sanity. Kratos' wife Lysandra (Jennifer Hale) and his daughter Calliope appear in an illusion created by Alecto, and the King of Sparta ([[Crispin Freeman]]) and the Village Oracle ([[Susan Blakeslee]]) appear in an illusion created by Tisiphone with the help of her [[Familiar spirit|familiar]], [[Daemon (classical mythology)|Daemon]].
In the game's multiplayer mode, [[Zeus]] ([[Corey Burton]]), the King of the Olympian Gods, Ares ([[Steven Blum]]), the God of War, [[Poseidon]] ([[Gideon Emery]]), the God of the Sea, and [[Hades]] ([[Fred Tatasciore]]), the God of the [[Greek underworld|Underworld]], appear as statues at the Rotunda of Olympus where the player selects one to align to, after which the chosen god will communicate with the player during gameplay. Castor and Pollux, the demigod [[Hercules]] ([[Kevin Sorbo]]), the Titan cyclops [[Polyphemus]], the Gorgon [[Stheno]], and the giant scorpion [[Scorpius#Mythology|Skorpius]] also appear in the multiplayer as [[Boss (video gaming)|bosses]] and/or environmental obstacles.
===Plot=== The game begins with Kratos, who is imprisoned, chained, and tormented by the Furies for breaking his blood oath to Ares. The Fury Megaera tortures Kratos, but he manages to break free. Chasing her through the prison, he discovers that the prison itself is [[Hekatonkheires|Aegaeon the Hecatonchires]], the first traitor of the Furies who had broken a blood oath to Zeus; he was turned into the Prison of the Damned as punishment.<ref name="preview">{{cite web|url=http://me.ign.com/en/preview/7443/watch-the-first-30-minutes-of-god-of-war-ascension |title=Watch the First 30 Minutes of God of War: Ascension |date=February 1, 2013 |author=IGN Staff |publisher=[[Ziff Davis Media]] |work=[[IGN]] |accessdate=February 4, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EBqhh0Xd?url=http://me.ign.com/en/preview/7443/watch-the-first-30-minutes-of-god-of-war-ascension |archivedate=February 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Overcoming an illusion created by the Fury Tisiphone and her familiar Daemon, Kratos finds and kills Megaera, retrieving the Amulet of [[Uroborus]], which the Furies had confiscated from him when he was imprisoned. [[File:GoWAscension Kratos vs Manticore QTE tethering.png|thumb|300px|[[Kratos (God of War)|Kratos]] battles the [[manticore]] at the Tower of Delphi. The screenshot demonstrates the new [[tether]]ing mechanic; it is being used in conjunction with the [[Quick time event|QTE]] mechanic.]] The narrative shifts to three weeks before Kratos' imprisonment. Confronted by Orkos in the Village of Kirra, Kratos is advised that the visions he has been experiencing are mind tricks created by the Furies, and instructs him to find the Oracle of Delphi. Upon arrival at the Temple of Delphi, he overcomes Castor and Pollux, who tried to kill the Oracle. In her dying breath, the Oracle instructs Kratos to travel to Delos to retrieve the Eyes of Truth. Taking the Amulet of Uroborus from the now-dead Castor and Pollux, Kratos travels to Kirra's harbor, where he again encounters Orkos. The oath keeper reveals that Ares wanted a perfect warrior to help him overthrow Zeus, so Ares [[God of War (2005 video game)#Plot|helped Kratos against the barbarians]] to make him into a perfect warrior. Orkos became the oath keeper and did not question the Furies until Ares tricked Kratos into killing his own family. Armed with this knowledge, Kratos takes a ship to Delos.
A week later, Kratos arrives at the island of Delos and explores the ruined statue of Apollo. He is attacked by all three Furies and is eventually captured. Orkos appears and frees Kratos, transporting him to another location. Orkos gives Kratos his Oath Stone and reveals that he and Aletheia tried to warn Zeus of Ares' and the Furies' plan. In retaliation, they took the Oracle's eyes, the objects Kratos seeks. After a perilous journey, Kratos uses the Amulet of Uroborus to restore the statue and retrieve the eyes. On completing the Trials of Archimedes, Kratos is ambushed and captured by the Furies, who confiscate all of his items.
Back in the present time, Tisiphone and Daemon cast another illusion to deceive Kratos, who overcomes it and retrieves the Oath Stone of Orkos. He encounters the Scribe of Hecatonchires, who reveals that the Furies were originally fair in their punishment, but devolved into ruthless beings because of Ares. Continuing his pursuit of the Furies, Kratos reaches the door to Alecto's Chamber, but seemingly returns home to his wife and daughter: another illusion, this time cast by the Fury Queen Alecto. She tries to convince Kratos he can live within this illusion if he rejoins Ares, but he refuses. Enraged, Alecto and Tisiphone attack Kratos, who retrieves the eyes, and Alecto transforms into a [[Charybdis|giant sea monster]]. After a brutal battle, Kratos uses the eyes to break through the Furies' illusions before killing them both, which destroys the prison.
Kratos returns to Sparta, where he is met by Orkos. He praises Kratos' victory over the Furies, but reveals that Kratos will not be free from Ares' bond unless he kills Orkos. He begs Kratos to give him an honorable death, which will free them both from Ares. Kratos initially refuses but Orkos' continuing pleas ultimately force Kratos to kill him. Afterward, Kratos experiences the first of many nightmares—previously masked by his bond—and discovers his path to redemption through continual service to Olympus. Kratos burns down his house with the corpse of Orkos inside and leaves, beginning his path towards becoming the champion of the gods.

The development team faced challenges in adding multiplayer to an established single-player franchise. Other established franchises had been criticized for sub-par multiplayer implementations, so Santa Monica felt they had to prove to critics that their multiplayer mode would not be "tacked on". Since multiplayer was new to the team, new staff were hired who specialized in multiplayer, engineering, and design, but Santa Monica did not realize the amount of work required for the experience they had envisioned. Development was delayed because multiplayer mode required several rewrites. The player navigation code had to be changed for online play, which was initially designed for co-op; the team eventually decided this was unsatisfactory, and the changed approach cost significant development time.<ref name="postmortem">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/193695/postmortem__sony_santa_monicas_.php?print=1 |title=Postmortem - Sony Santa Monica's God of War: Ascension |issue=June/July 2013 |author=Wade, Whitney and Chacko Sonny |publisher=[[UBM TechWeb]] |work=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=March 16, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510120038/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/193695/postmortem__sony_santa_monicas_.php?print=1 |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> [[Multiplayer video game#Single-system|Local co-op]] was also explored, but the team decided to keep multiplayer online-only.<ref name="3D & local co-op">{{cite web|url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2013/03/07/god-of-war-ascension-3d-support-and-local-co-op-in-trial-of-the-gods-were-explored-ultimately-determined-not-to-pursue-further/ |title=God of War: Ascension – 3D Support and Local Co-op in Trial of the Gods Were Explored, "Ultimately Determined not to Pursue Further" |date=March 7, 2013 |last=Dunning |first=Jason |publisher=[[CraveOnline]] |work=[[PlayStation LifeStyle]] |accessdate=January 28, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6gs0vjXIq?url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2013/03/07/god-of-war-ascension-3d-support-and-local-co-op-in-trial-of-the-gods-were-explored-ultimately-determined-not-to-pursue-further/ |archivedate=April 18, 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> The team finally "found the heart of [the] final multiplayer game" shortly before the first press show. Development focus switched back and forth between single-player and multiplayer; single-player received less attention while the team were preparing multiplayer for the first press announcement, but when single-player mode was reemphasized prior to its public debut, multiplayer mode suffered.<ref name="postmortem"/>
David Jaffe, creator and Game Director of the original ''God of War'', spoke with ''NowGamer'' prior to the first press announcement in late April. He said that if he had worked on ''Ascension'', he would have incorporated three specific elements: different myths, a co-star, and "look to the ''[[The Legend of Zelda|Zelda]]'' structure as a jumping off point".<ref name="JaffeNowGamer"/> He liked the idea of a cooperative mode, and added "I'd love to see player one be Kratos and player two be this stupid annoying sidekick that—for some to be determined story reason—Kratos is stuck with for the whole adventure and in the end, once the main quest is over, Kratos just snaps the poor kid's neck".<ref name="JaffeNowGamer">{{cite web|url=http://www.nowgamer.com/news/1339782/god_of_war_ascension_jaffe_reveals_ideas_for_next_kratos_adventure.html |title=God Of War: Ascension: Jaffe Reveals Ideas For Next Kratos Adventure |date=April 26, 2012 |last=Hopkins |first=Tom |publisher=[[Imagine Publishing]] |work=NowGamer |accessdate=August 7, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch6qkKfM?url=http://www.nowgamer.com/news/1339782/god_of_war_ascension_jaffe_reveals_ideas_for_next_kratos_adventure.html |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> In May 2012, Jaffe spoke with [[IGN]] about the multiplayer element: "I think it looks cool. It looks like another great, impeccably executed Sony Santa Monica game", and added, "If it turns out to be the case that the single player is watered down because of [multiplayer], then I think they have some justification. But I don't see any evidence of that, and I don't see evidence of that based on the team they are."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/05/04/god-of-war-3-multiplayer-jaffe-on-ascension |title=God of War 3 Multiplayer, Jaffe on Ascension |date=May 3, 2012 |last=Miller |first=Greg |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |work=[[IGN]] |accessdate=March 13, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X6C2pxhZ?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/05/04/god-of-war-3-multiplayer-jaffe-on-ascension |archivedate=March 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
===Post-E3 2012=== At Sony's [[E3 2012|2012]] [[Electronic Entertainment Expo]] (E3) press conference, the North American release date was confirmed as March 12, 2013. A single-player demo was shown, revealing new gameplay mechanics and combat systems.<ref name="E312"/> An encounter with the sea monster [[Charybdis]] was included in the demo, but this sequence was cut from the final game. Charybdis was recast as the creature that Alecto transforms into during the final fight of the game.<ref name="Charybdis">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/09/16/qa-the-art-of-god-of-war-ascension/ |title=Q&A: The Art of God of War: Ascension |date=September 16, 2013 |last=Kaufman |first=Aaron |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=February 24, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X6CDiSnf?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/09/16/qa-the-art-of-god-of-war-ascension/ |archivedate=March 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> The same day, Papy confirmed on [[PlayStation.Blog]] that a collector's edition of the game would be released. He said ''Ascension'' was being developed to feature [[Stereoscopy|stereoscopic 3D]],<ref name="06/04">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/06/04/e3-2012-god-of-war-ascension-unleashes-on-ps3-next-march/|title=E3 2012: God of War: Ascension Unleashes on PS3 Next March|date=June 4, 2012|last=Papy|first=Todd|publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]]|work=[[PlayStation.Blog]]|accessdate=June 6, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch5d4VnU?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/06/04/e3-2012-god-of-war-ascension-unleashes-on-ps3-next-march/|archivedate=December 5, 2012}}</ref> but it was ultimately cut.<ref name="3D & local co-op"/> At [[gamescom 2012]], new multiplayer footage was shown, followed by the announcement of a multiplayer [[Betaware|beta]].<ref name="beta" /> [[File:Kratos GoW3 vs Ascension.jpg|thumb|right|Comparison of [[Kratos (God of War)|Kratos]] as he appears in ''[[God of War III]]'' (top) and ''Ascension'' (bottom). Increasing the [[UV mapping|UV]] sets gave Kratos a more realistic appearance in ''Ascension''.]] At the 2012 [[Penny Arcade Expo]] (PAX), Game Director Todd Papy, Lead Game Designer Mark Simon, Principal Character Artist Patrick Murphy, and writer of the ''God of War'' series [[Marianne Krawczyk]], hosted the first ''God of War'' panel, discussing the origins of ''Ascension'', and provided an overview of the evolution of Kratos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/08/28/playstation-at-pax-2012-god-of-war-ascension-all-stars-littlebigplanet-and-more/ |title=PlayStation at PAX 2012: God of War: Ascension, All-Stars, LittleBigPlanet and More |date=August 28, 2012 |last=Cardona |first=Cristian |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=August 29, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch6sJT3Y?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/08/28/playstation-at-pax-2012-god-of-war-ascension-all-stars-littlebigplanet-and-more/ |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> The Fury Megaera was revealed,<ref name="Furies">{{cite web|url=http://www.g4tv.com/thefeed/blog/post/727543/god-of-war-ascension-enemies-revealed-meet-the-furies/ |title=God of War: Ascension Enemies Revealed; Meet the Furies |date=August 31, 2012 |last=Gaskill |first=Jake |publisher=[[G4 Media]] |work=[[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4tv.com]] |accessdate=September 1, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CWQ6KGN8?url=http://www.g4tv.com/thefeed/blog/post/727543/god-of-war-ascension-enemies-revealed-meet-the-furies/ |archivedate=November 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> and Mark Simon discussed the new combat system. Papy said he had considered using the goddess [[Artemis]] as a playable female character, which would have offered the player alternative combat options. Artemis would have been depicted as half-human and half-feline, with the head and torso of a woman and the legs of a lioness. Artemis was ultimately cut from the game, but Papy said he would like to explore the possibility of using other gods in the future.<ref name="PAX">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/08/29/pax-2012-god-of-war-ascension-panel-is-friday-attend-for-beta-access/ |title=Watch the PAX 2012 God of War: Ascension Panel |date=August 29, 2012 |last=Kaufman |first=Aaron |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=September 1, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch6t8QxQ?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/08/29/pax-2012-god-of-war-ascension-panel-is-friday-attend-for-beta-access/ |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
In the developmental transition from ''God of War III'' to ''Ascension'', one of the graphics engineers, Cedric Perthuis, noted that the limits of the ''God of War III'' engine restricted artist creativity, so they "tried to remove or push those limits as far as possible without losing any performance."<ref name="MasteredPS3"/> For example, the number of [[UV mapping|UV]] sets was increased to three per mesh. For a complex character model like Kratos, "independent textures are needed for body parts unique to him, each wrapping around the head, torso and limbs - all of which form an editable 'UV set' when laid out flat."<ref name="MasteredPS3"/> Allowing more UV sets also made it possible to have a more natural look to the environment. ''Ascension'' was not as dramatic an advance in graphics over its predecessor as ''God of War III'' had been: "From a graphics 'technical' perspective, to a large degree ''God of War: Ascension'' was more refinement on the graphics front" said another graphics engineer, Ben Diamand, who focused on optimization during ''Ascension''{{'}}s development.<ref name="MasteredPS3"/> The development team also added [[dynamic lighting]], which allowed for development of the Life Cycle gameplay mechanic. Particle effects were also greatly improved from ''God of War III'': "the idea was to give artists more control to achieve better results with less particles" said Perthuis.<ref name="MasteredPS3">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/digitalfoundry-how-sony-santa-monica-mastered-the-ps3 |title=How Sony Santa Monica mastered PlayStation 3 |date=May 4, 2013 |last=Morgan |first=Thomas |publisher=Eurogamer Network |work=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=February 24, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X6CH5qxB?url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/digitalfoundry-how-sony-santa-monica-mastered-the-ps3 |archivedate=March 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
Terrence C. Carson, Linda Hunt, Corey Burton, Gideon Emery, Steven Blum, and Kevin Sorbo reprised their roles as Kratos, the narrator, Zeus, Poseidon, Ares, and Hercules, respectively. Jennifer Hale, who voiced two characters in the [[God of War: Ghost of Sparta|previous installment]], voiced the Fury Alecto and Kratos' wife, Lysandra, who was previously voiced by [[Gwendoline Yeo]]. Debi Mae West, Adrienne Barbeau, and Crispin Freeman, who had each done voice work on previous installments, voiced the characters Tisiphone, Aletheia, and the King of Sparta. Troy Baker voiced the oath keeper Orkos and is the announcer in the multiplayer mode. Series veteran Fred Tatasciore assumed the role of Hades, who was previously voiced by [[Clancy Brown]]. Susan Blakeslee reprised her role as the Village Oracle, who makes a cameo appearance as an illusion created by Tisiphone. Unlike previous games in which [[motion capture]] and [[voice over|voice recording]] were done separately, ''Ascension'' used "voice-over motion capture"; voice recording and motion capture were done at the same time, which allowed the voice actors to act out their characters' scenes together. The voice-over motion capture was done at House of Moves in [[Culver City, California]].<ref>{{cite video|title=God of War: Ascension: Unchained – Kratos Comes to Life|publisher=[[SCE Santa Monica Studio]]|year=2013}}</ref>
===Multiplayer beta=== A global multiplayer beta was announced at gamescom 2012.<ref name="beta">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/08/14/are-you-ready-for-the-god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-beta/ |title=Are You Ready for the God of War: Ascension Multiplayer Beta? |date=August 14, 2012 |last=Papy |first=Todd |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=August 15, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch67LgMr?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/08/14/are-you-ready-for-the-god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-beta/ |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> The beta included features that had not been previously revealed. Players who participated in the ''Rise of the Warrior'' social challenge on GodofWar.com received early access to the beta in December 2012.<ref name="Rise">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/10/22/god-of-war-ascension-new-trailer-rise-of-the-warrior-early-beta-access/ |title=God of War: Ascension: New Trailer, Rise of the Warrior, Early Beta Access |date=October 22, 2012 |last=Papy |first=Todd |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=October 23, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ch6u9s8S?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2012/10/22/god-of-war-ascension-new-trailer-rise-of-the-warrior-early-beta-access/ |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Players from [[Sony Computer Entertainment Europe|SCE Europe]] also received an opportunity to access the beta early.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.eu.playstation.com/2012/11/30/we-need-you-for-the-god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-beta/ |title=We need YOU for the God of War: Ascension multiplayer beta |date=November 30, 2012 |last=Alexander |first=Ross |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment Europe]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CnkBmbqB?url=http://blog.eu.playstation.com/2012/11/30/we-need-you-for-the-god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-beta/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> The beta became available for [[PlayStation Network#PlayStation Plus|PlayStation Plus]] subscribers on January 8, 2013.<ref name="Jan 8"/><ref name="PAX"/> On January 19, Santa Monica allowed all [[PlayStation Network]] users in North and South America access to the beta via a redeemable voucher. The beta test ended at midnight [[Pacific Time Zone|Pacific time]] on January 21.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/01/19/god-of-war-ascension-mp-beta-open-to-all-psn-users-for-a-very-limited-time/ |title=God of War: Ascension Multiplayer Beta Opens to All PSN Users |date=January 19, 2013 |last=Jabbari |first=Aram |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=January 20, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Do5f66lT?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/01/19/god-of-war-ascension-mp-beta-open-to-all-psn-users-for-a-very-limited-time/ |archivedate=January 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> In the beta, players could choose to align themselves with Ares or Zeus. It featured the eight-player Desert of Lost Souls map and the four-player Forum of Hercules map. The beta included the Desert of Lost Souls map in the modes Team Favor of the Gods and Capture the Flag, and the Forum of Hercules map in the mode Favor of the Gods, renamed Match of Champions in final release.<ref name="Jan 8">{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/01/08/god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-beta-begins-today-for-playstation-plus/ |title=God of War Ascension Multiplayer Beta Begins Today for PlayStation Plus |date=January 8, 2013 |last=Kaufman |first=Aaron |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=January 8, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DWgpYlnF?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/01/08/god-of-war-ascension-multiplayer-beta-begins-today-for-playstation-plus/ |archivedate=January 8, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> All participants of the beta received the Champion's Armor and Blade for their multiplayer character when the game launched.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/01/11/god-of-war-ascension-beta-rewards-penny-arcades-book-of-divine-wisdom/ |title=God of War: Ascension Beta Rewards, Penny Arcade’s Book of Divine Wisdom |date=January 11, 2013 |last=Kaufman |first=Aaron |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America]] |work=[[PlayStation.Blog]] |accessdate=January 11, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DbelcYsm?url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/01/11/god-of-war-ascension-beta-rewards-penny-arcades-book-of-divine-wisdom/ |archivedate=January 12, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
According to Santa Monica's senior producer Whitney Wade and director of internal development Chacko Sonny, the beta made the team look at the game as an "evolving service".<ref name="postmortem"/> The beta allowed the developers to make sure that the game design would meet with the approval of existing fans of the series, and that the system could cope with a high volume of players. Wade and Sonny said the testing went as expected, "revealing successive layers of issues that we would address, deploy fixes for, and then monitor in a live environment."<ref name="postmortem"/> The most important change from the beta, they said, was their planning in how to support the game post-launch. The team designed a process that allowed them to "quickly iterate on fixes, deploy them through infrastructure (testing, certification, patching), and coordinate with internal technology partners within Sony."<ref name="postmortem"/> They also developed a system to allow them to monitor, log, and interpret any changes added, and the beta test gave insight on how to prioritize key features.<ref name="postmortem"/>

===''Rise of the Warrior''=== ''Rise of the Warrior'' was a [[graphic novel]] by Marianne Krawczyk with art by [[Christopher Shy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/10/22/earn-xp-in-god-of-war-ascension-today |title=Earn XP in God of War: Ascension Today |date=October 22, 2012 |last=Miller |first=Greg |publisher=[[Ziff Davis Media]] |work=[[IGN]] |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cnj7Xf6Z?url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/10/22/earn-xp-in-god-of-war-ascension-today |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Only available on GodofWar.com,{{efn|As of 2015, ''Rise of the Warrior'' is no longer available on GodofWar.com.}} it was a prequel story that tied into ''Ascension''{{'}}s single-player and multiplayer modes, and had 20 chapters that were released from October 2012 to March 2013. It also featured a [[Social network game|social experience]] during that same time period. For the social experience, players were aligned with either the Spartans or the Trojans and competed via social challenges to earn points, such as answering questions and solving riddles for each chapter. In the first challenge, the teams competed to earn their army a week of exclusive, early access to the multiplayer beta test that began on December 12, and a one-month subscription to PlayStation Plus, which was won by the Spartans; the Trojans received access on December 17. The Spartans also won the next team challenge and received early access to the Prison of the Damned single-player demo on February 20, 2013.<ref name="newdemo"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nowgamer.com/news/1780208/god_of_war_ascension_get_early_access_to_the_singleplayer_demo.html |title=God Of War: Ascension – Get Early Access To The Single-Player Demo |date=January 24, 2013 |last=Lynch |first=David |publisher=[[Imagine Publishing]] |work=NowGamer |accessdate=January 27, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DyefiKq4?url=http://www.nowgamer.com/news/1780208/god_of_war_ascension_get_early_access_to_the_singleplayer_demo.html |archivedate=January 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Players could also earn early, in-game unlocks for the final game's multiplayer mode, including exclusive weapons and armor for all players who attained the rank of Champion of the Gods.<ref name="Rise"/>
The story followed an unnamed warrior who became the player's character in the multiplayer mode. The warrior was a native of Kirra whose father was killed by a cruel general who poisoned the water supply of the village, killing many people. Before dying, the warrior's father beckoned him to honor the gods and swear to never let harm come to their family. The warrior swore his father's oath and was met by a cloaked figure, The Giver, who guided him and followed him throughout his journey.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|November 2012|loc=Ch 3: The Beginning}}</ref> Soon after, the warrior called upon Ares to save his people from the poisonous water; the god destroyed the aqueduct and water wheel that supplied water to the village. The warrior then encountered the surviving soldiers who had been under his father's command.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|November 2012|loc=Ch 5: The Flood}}</ref> One soldier told the warrior that swords alone could not defeat the general.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|November 2012|loc=Ch 6: A Dark Presence}}</ref> The warrior and his men traveled to the land of [[Aeaea]] and recruited the witch [[Circe]], who seemingly also sought revenge against the general.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|December 2012|loc=Ch 7: Circe's Temple}}</ref> Circe granted the soldiers magical weapons to aid them on their journey, and suggested that they see the Oracle of Delphi to discover whether the general had any weaknesses.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|December 2012|loc=Ch 8: The Gem of Uroborus}}</ref> During this time, the warrior vowed loyalty to Poseidon and to protect his men.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|December 2012|loc=Ch 9: The Lord of the Sea}}</ref>
After traveling through Delphi, the warrior obtained the venomous blood of a cerberus.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|January 2013|loc=Ch 13: A Powerful Poison}}</ref> Eventually, both Circe and the warrior encountered the general, who was revealed to be the warrior's uncle. The general revealed that he killed the warrior's father because he refused to join the general.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|January 2013|loc=Ch 15: Dark Patriarch}}</ref> Circe was then revealed to be the general's lover who had only aided the warrior so he would reach the general, who planned to offer the warrior a chance to serve him in his warmongering conquests. The warrior refused, and Circe offered him with a choice; to serve the general and his men would be spared from Circe's wrath, or to kill the general and his men shall die.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|February 2013|loc=Ch 16: The Offer}}</ref> The Giver, who followed the two, reminded the warrior that if he were to kill the general, who was a member of his family, the oath he made to his father would be broken, yet if he killed Circe, his men would perish and the oath he made to protect his men would be broken.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|February 2013|loc=Ch 17: The Choice}}</ref> The warrior declared that he would not slay Circe and defended the lives of his men. However, he tricked the general into drinking from a cup he had secretly filled with the cerberus's blood, which killed the general. Circe was aghast at the warrior's vengeful act and retreated.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|February 2013|loc=Ch 18: Vengeance}}</ref> Because the warrior killed his own uncle, the oath he made to his father was broken. The Giver revealed himself to be Orkos, the oath keeper of the Furies and the warrior was imprisoned by the Furies in the Prison of the Damned.<ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|February 2013|loc=Ch 19: Orkos}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|ref=RotW|Krawczyk,|March 2013|loc=Ch 20: Prison of the Damned}}</ref>

==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = God of War: Ascension (Original Soundtrack) | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Tyler Bates]] | cover = | border = yes | alt = | released = {{Start date|2013|03|05}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Contemporary classical music]] | length = 1:05:35 | label = [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] and La-La Land Records | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }}
''God of War: Ascension (Original Soundtrack)'' was composed by [[Tyler Bates]] and was released on [[iTunes]] on March 5, 2013 by SCE and La-La Land Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/god-war-ascension-original/id606539183|title=God of War: Ascension (Original Soundtrack)|publisher=[[Apple Inc.]]|work=[[iTunes]]|accessdate=March 6, 2013}}</ref> It was included as DLC in the ''God of War: Ascension—Collector's Edition'' and ''Special Edition''.<ref name="06/04" /><ref name="Unboxing"/> On October 15, the soundtrack was made available for free on PSN for a limited time.<ref name="NoMoreDLC"/> A notable feature of ''Ascension''{{'}}s soundtrack is that it was scored by only one composer; all the previous games had multiple composers. Tyler Bates previously scored the similarly themed film ''300'' and game ''[[Rise of the Argonauts]]''. Bates said "My goal was to create a sound that supported the timeless dark age of ''God of War'', while expanding the parameters of the '[[Peplum (film genre)|Sword and Sandals]]' genre." Although the game's story is linear, he approached the project as if he were scoring a novel as opposed to a film. Bates did not play any of the previous games and chose not to in order to take the score "to new places without being overtly aware of the great music that is emblematic" of the prior installments. The soundtrack was recorded at [[Abbey Road Studios]], and features solo vocal work from Rafe Pearlman and Ciscandra Nostalghia.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes|title=God of War: Ascension (Original Soundtrack)|year=2013|first=Tyler|last=Bates|author-link=Tyler Bates|type=[[Liner notes|booklet]]|pp=3-4|publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment]], La-La Land Records}}</ref>
Throughout the score, Bates uses a combination of techniques "to increase the drama of the game" said Emily McMillan of Game Music Online, who gave the album a 4 out of 5 stars. She said one of Bates's signature techniques is "an intense and simultaneous crescendo and glissando." All of the themes take place on a [[harmonic minor scale]]. On the track, "Warriors' Truth", Bates used [[Gerard Marino]]'s main ''God of War'' theme and "twists it for the prequel setting", "taking the harmonic ascending scale and reverting it to a downwards pattern with a harsh choir/brass combination." The track "Visions of Ruin" features the [[cimbalom]], which is rarely used in video game soundtracks. She said overall "The music is powerful, rich, and pulsing", though listening to the whole album can seem repetitive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/godofwarascension/ |title=God of War -Ascension- Original Soundtrack |date=September 2, 2014 |last=McMillan |first=Emily |publisher=Game Music Online |accessdate=February 24, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X6DGsmOd?url=http://www.vgmonline.net/godofwarascension/ |archivedate=March 17, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>

''God of War: Ascension'' received generally favorable reviews upon release. Aggregating review websites [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] gave it an average review score of 79.34% (based on 58 reviews)<ref name="grankingscore"/> and 80/100 (based on 89 reviews),<ref name="metascore"/> respectively. Critics praised the fundamental gameplay and spectacle, but were critical of the lack of new ideas and gave a mixed response to the additional multiplayer mode. Alex Simmons of IGN said the redesigned combat system adds a source of depth: "Learning how to use each power effectively ... provides a strategic lifeline when there's no energy re-gen chest nearby". Although he initially found the World Weapons useful, he felt that they became unnecessary after upgrading the Blades of Chaos. Simmons felt the magic system was a "positive step"; since magic attacks are unlocked at a later time, players cannot rely on them as much as they may have done in previous installments, which encourages players "to think wisely about where to allocate experience points rather than being the ultimate badass from the outset".<ref name="IGNreview"/>
Combat and the new gameplay mechanics were well-received, with Dale North of [[Destructoid]] saying "''God of War'' has never looked or played better than this",<ref name="destructoid"/> and Xav de Matos of Joystiq commenting that the combat is simpler than in ''God of War III'', and rarely required much adjustment.<ref name="Joystiq"/> Opinions on difficulty varied; Simmons felt that most of the gameplay was balanced, and that ''Ascension'' "is probably the easiest" in the series, but both he and Hollander Cooper of [[GamesRadar]] commented that some areas, such as the Trials of Archimedes, were too difficult. Simmons felt that in some sections, the many enemies made dying feel "cheap and frustrating",<ref name="IGNreview"/> and in Cooper's opinion, some points in the game "[test] your patience, rather than your skills—including one [the Trials] that's easily the most difficult section in any ''God of War'' game to date, for all the wrong reasons".<ref name="gradar"/>
Both Simmons and Matos criticized the story; Simmons felt that although the narrative is "meticulously delivered", it "felt a bit incidental", and said that in comparison to Zeus and Ares, "the Furies don't quite cut it".<ref name="IGNreview"/> Matos was critical of the plot framing and the narrative structure as "just too chaotic"; he argued that "the narrative fabric woven throughout the franchise has begun to split", and ''Ascension'' does little to enhance its characters "in any meaningful way". He did praise the game for providing the "distinct ''God of War'' flair" known to the series.<ref name="Joystiq"/>
Cooper praised the enhanced graphics engine as "not only the best the franchise has seen, but some of the most impressive on the PlayStation 3", and was impressed by Kratos' foes.<ref name="gradar"/> North agreed, saying "there's a shine and polish that runs throughout the game that makes it a perfect send-off for the PS3", noting its improved textures, animations, and lighting.<ref name="destructoid"/> The review from ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]'' magazine also positively reviewed the graphics, but had some frustrations with the visual approach, such as some camera angles.<ref name="Edge"/>
Matos was broadly critical of the game's multiplayer mode, though he singled out some elements, such as the maps, as well-designed. He disliked the connection to single-player mode, calling it "a weird narrative tie-in", and was concerned that although the gameplay translates well into the multiplayer element, "the entire experience may be too chaotic to enrapture a large audience ... it doesn't feel deep enough to command much more than a furiously dedicated fan following".<ref name="Joystiq"/> Simmons was more positive, saying that the multiplayer mode is "a genuinely fresh addition ... that successfully carries over many of the hallmarks of the much-loved single-player [game]". He singled out Team Favor of the Gods as his favorite mode, but did not feel that the combat offered enough depth to make multiplayer "a truly engaging experience", describing it instead as "a curiosity that provides a few hours of enjoyment rather than being an essential addition".<ref name="IGNreview"/> The review from ''Edge'' magazine described multiplayer mode as "chaotic at first", with overwhelming options, but said that it becomes easier as players learn the levels. The ''Edge'' review identified the fixed camera system as an asset because "you can always see exactly what's going on and fight your opponents instead of the viewpoint", and also praised the color-coding system, which "effectively lets you know when you have an opening and when to run".<ref name="Edge"/>
===Controversy=== Some reviewers disliked the title of one of the game's trophies, "Bros before Hos", which is received after graphically face-stomping a female villain. In response to the criticisms of misogyny, Santa Monica released a patch changing the name of the trophy to "Bros before Foes".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2013/03/11/controversial-god-of-war-ascension-trophy-altered-in-upcoming-p/ |title=Controversial God of War: Ascension trophy altered in upcoming patch |last=Matos |first=Xav de |publisher=[[AOL]] |work=[[Joystiq]] |date=March 11, 2013 |accessdate=March 13, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6F60x5OVh?url=http://www.joystiq.com/2013/03/11/controversial-god-of-war-ascension-trophy-altered-in-upcoming-p/ |archivedate=March 13, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
